respStmt.resp: Initial encoding completed on March 10, 2019 by
Prosopography IDs, terms, and notes determined by

publicationStmt.publisher: Lili Elbe Digital Archive, Loyola University

sourceDesc.p: People and Places encoded in this file are pulled from the following linked LEDA texts: American Edition British Edition German Edition Danish Edition English Translation of Danish Edition German Typescript English Translation of German Typescript Danish Language Archive/Supplemental Materials German Language Archive/Supplemental Materials Danish Language Archive/Supplemental Materials

listPlace.head: List of places mentioned in Lili Elbe Digital Archive

place.note: Art Academy (fictional), modeled on The Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts (Det Kongelige Danske Kunstakademi) in Copenhagen, where Einar and Gerda Wegener studied and met
Africa is a continent south of Europe. Gerda Wegener lived in Morocco in northern Africa with her second husband.
Aix (historical), city in Germany
Alexandria (historical), a city in Egypt
Alps (historical), a mountain range in Europe
Anhalter Banhof (historical), the main train station in Berlin, no longer in existence
Antwerp (historical), a city in Belgium
America (historical), commonly used to refer to the United States of America
Amsterdam (historical), capital of the Netherlands
Australia (historical), a continent and a country surrounded by the Indian Ocean whose capital is Canberra.
Balgencie (fictional), modeled on Beaugency, a town on the Loire river in southern France
Balkans (historical), region in southeastern Europe
Beaugency (historical), a town on the Loire river in southern France
Belgium (historical), a country in western Europe whose capital is Brussels.
Berlin (historical), capital of Germany
Bernstorff Castle (historical), Bernstorff Palace in Gentofte, Copenhagen
Bohemia (historical), a region of the Czech Republic
Brandenburg Gate (historical), an 18th-century monument, among the best-known landmarks in Berlin
Cádiz (historical), port city in Spain
Capri (histoical), island off Italy in the Gulf of Naples
Cathedral of Seville (historical), most likely, Catedral de Santa María de la Sede, known as Seville Cathedral
Cairo (historical), capital of Egypt
Chambord (historical), commune in France
Champs de Mars (historical), a park in Paris
Château neuf du Pape (fictional), no known historical analogue
Copenhagen (historical), capital of Denmark
Cologne (historical), city in Germany
Denmark is a Scandinavian country in northern Europe whose capital is Copenhagen.
Dolomites Mountain Range(historical), a mountain range in Italy
Drei Masken (historical), a German publishing house
Dresden (historical), city in Germany
Ecole des Beaux Arts (historical), École nationale supérieure des Beaux-Arts, the most famous school of the fine arts in Paris
Egypt (historical), a country in northeast Africa whose capital is Cairo.
Eiffel Tower (historical), the most famous Parisian landmark, constructed in 1887

place.placeName: the banks of the broad stream
place.note: The banks of the Elbe River (historical); a river in Central Europe that runs through Dresden
Elbe River (historical), river in Central Europe that runs through Dresden
England (historical), a country of the United Kingdom
Erzgebirge (historical), mountain range in eastern Germany
Europe (historical), a continent in the Northern Hemisphere
Facciano (historical), no known historical analogue
Florence (historical), city in Italy
France is a western European country whose capital is Paris.

Northern France (historical), France is a western European country. We had to distinguish Northern France from France because in some languages Northern France is one word and can signify a specific identity.

Southern France (historical), France is a western European country. We had to distinguish Southern France from France because in some languages Southern France is one word and can signify a specific identity.
Friedrichsstrasse (historical), a street in Berlin
Gebhard’s sanitorium (fictional), possibly modeled on Erwin Gohrbandt’s private clinic at Augsburger Str. 66, Berlin
Gedser (historical), town in southern Denmark
Gentofte Lake (historical), near Copenhagen
Germany is a western European country whose capital is Berlin.

Southern German (historical), Germany is a western European country. We had to distinguish South Germany from Germany because in some languages South Germany is one word and can signify a specific identity.

Northern Germany (historical), Germany is a western European country. We had to distinguish North Germany from Germany because in some languages North Germany is one word and can signify a specific identity.
Greece is a southeastern European country whose capital is Athens.
Gipsy Bar (fictional), no known historical analogue
The Hague (historical), city in the Netherlands
Hanover (historical), also spelled Hannover, city in Germany
Hindustan (historical), a Persian name for India
Holland (the Netherlands, historical), a country in northwestern Europe whose capital is Amsterdam.

place.placeName: one of the numerous small hotels in Paris
place.note: Hôtel D’Alsace (historical), small hotel in Saint Germain, Paris
Hôtel des Reservoirs (historical), at that time a hotel on rue des Réservoirs near the park of Versailles
Hungary (historical), a country in Central Europe

Institute for Psychiatry (fictional), modeled on the Institut Für Sexualwissenschaft (Institute for Sexual Science) in Berlin, founded by Magnus Hirschfeld in 1919; Einar Wegener was initially examined there
Italy is a European country whose capital is Rome.
Jutland (historical), the largest region of Denmark
North Jutland (historical), Jutand is a region of Denmark. We had to distinguish North Jutland from Jutland because in some languages North Jutland is one word and can signify a specific identity.
Kurfuürstendamm (historical), an upscale avenue in Berlin whose Jewish-owned shops were targeted during Kristallnacht in 1938

place.placeName: dem Laboratorium des Biochemikers Doktor Karner
place.note: Karner’s laboratory (fictional), no known historical analogue
Place de l’Alma (historical), a bridge in Paris open to traffic
Lapi (fictional), no known historical analogue
Leipziger Strasse (historical), a major boulevard in Berlin
Lindevangen (historical), a street in Frederiksberg, Denmark
Loire River (historical), the longest river in France
Banks of Loire River (historical); the longest river in France
London (historical), capital of England
Madrid (historical), capital of Spain
Marrakech (historical), a city in Morocco
Mallorca (historical), a Spanish island
Piccola Marina (historical), a marina in Capri
Montmartre (historical), a hilltop section of Paris, renowned locate for artists and intellectuals in the 1920s
Monte Tiberio (historical), on the island of Capri
Morgano (fictional), no known historical analogue
Morocco (historical), a country in northern Africa
Naples (historical), city in Italy
Neustadt (historical), Dresdner Neustadt, on the right bank of the Elbe, Dresden
Norway is a Scandinavian country in northern Europe whose capital is Oslo.
Oslo (historical), capital of Norway
Öresund (historical), also spelled Øresund; a strait running between Denmark and Sweden
Orvieto (historical), hilltop city in Italy
Palazzo Chigi (historical), a 15th-century palace named after the Chigi family
Paris (historical), capital of France
Pariser Platz (historical), central square in Berlin near the Brandenburg Gate
Passy (historical), an upscale neighborhood in Paris, home of many avant-garde artists in the 1920s
Poland (historical), a country in Central Europe
Phisters Street (historical), Phistersvej is a street in a suburb of Copenhagen
Piazza Colonna (historical), site of the famous Column of Marcus Aurelius in Rome
L'Edition d'Art H. Piazza (historical), French publisher
Piazza de Spagna (historical), a piazza at the bottom of the Spanish Steps in Rome
Piazza Vittorio Emanuele (historical), a monument in Rome built in the 19th century and named after Vittoria Emanuele II, the first king of Italy after unification (1861-1878).
Pompeii (historical), an ancient Roman city
Potsdamer Platz (historical), central square in Berlin
Quartier Saint Germain (historical), also known as the Latin Quarter (see D1), section of Paris
Rathausplatz (German spelling, historical), Rådhuspladsen is the central square in Copenhagen
Hôtel des Reservoirs (historical), at that time a hotel on rue des Réservoirs near the park of Versailles
Romanisches Café (see TS), renowned gathering place for intellectuals and artists in Berlin in the 1920s
Rome (historical), capital of Italy
Rothenburg (historical), a medieval town in Bavaria
Sacré-Coeur (historical), a Roman Catholic church in Paris
Salon d'Automne (historical), annual art exhibit in Paris begun in 1903
Thessaloniki (historical), a city in Greece
Saxony (historical), a state in eastern Germany
Scandinavia (historical), a region in northern Europe encompassing the countries of Denmark, Norway, and Sweden
Seine (historical), river that runs through Paris
Bridges of the Seine (historical), river that runs through Paris
Banks of the Seine (historical); a river that runs through Paris
Seville (historical), a city in southern Spain
Spain is a European country on the Iberian Peninsula whose capital is Madrid.
Gare du Nord (historical), a train station in Paris
St. Croix (historical), an island in the Caribbean once part of the Danish West Indies
Church (historical) in Latin Quartier, Paris
Strog (historical), actually “Strøget,” the main shopping street in Copenhagen, closed to traffic
the Wegeners’ studio (historical), located on rue de Lille in Paris
Sweden (historical), a Scandinavian country in Northern Europe
Sydney (historical), a city in Australia
Tauentzienstrasse (historical), a shopping street in Berlin
The Danish Royal Theater (historical), located in Copenhagen
Thomasiusstrasse (historical), a street in the residential section of Berlin
Tiergarten (historical), Berlin’s largest park, a popular meeting-place for homosexual men at the time
Grand Trianon (historical), a palace on the estate of Versailles outside Paris
Turkey (historical), a country in the Middle East whose capital is Ankara.
Ullstein (historical), a German publishing house
Unter den Linden (historical), a street in Berlin
Vejle (historical), Einar Wegener’s birthplace in the Jutland region of Denmark
Versailles (historical), a royal palace outside Paris
grounds of Versailles (historical), a royal palace outside Paris
Palace of Versailles (historical), a royal palace outside Paris
Vienna (historical), a city in Austria
Boulangerie Viennoise (historical), a Viennese bakery in Paris
Vineta (fictional), a mythological city in the Baltic Sea
Warnemünde (historical), a German city located near the Baltic Sea
Municipal Women’s Clinic (fictional), modeled on Staatliche Frauenklinik in Dresden, directed by Professor Kurt Warenkros at the time
Zürich (historical), city in northern Switzerland

listPerson.head: List of people mentioned in Lili Elbe Digital Archive

person.note: Eric Allatini (1886–1943), friend of the Wegeners, a writer of fairy tales and a musician, who was of Italian origin; married to Hélène Allatini
Hélène Kann Allatini (1887-1943), friend of the Wegeners; author of Mosaiques, with a chapter on Lili Elbe
Joselyn Allatini (1918-1947), daughter of Hélène Kann Allatini
Hans Christian Andersen (1805-1875), a famous Danish author known for his fairy tales
Aphrodites (fictional), in Greek mythology, the goddess of love and beauty proclaimed by Homer to be the daughter of Zeus
Joan of Arc (1412-1431), soldier in the Hundred Years’ War and a Roman Catholic saint; fought in the Battle of Beaugency in 1429
Professor Arns (fictional), also Arno; possibly modeled on Arthur Weil, who invented a bold test and worked at Magnus Hirschfeld’s Institute in Berlin
Bach (historical), Johann Sebastian Bach (1685–1750), a German composer
Bonsels (historical), possibly Waldemar Bonsels (1880-1952), a German author, though he was an avowed anti-Semite and approved the Nazis policies toward Jews
Sandro Botticelli (1445-1510), an Italian Renaissance painter
Bourbons (historical), royal family who ruled France for two centuries
Karen Bramson (1875-1936), a Danish author
Oscar Brandstetter Verlag (historical), a German publisher

person.persName: bride of Pianist XX of Hanover
person.note: bride (fictional), no known historical model
Christian (fictional), Andreas’s brother-in-law; modeled on Thomas Christian Thomsen (1883-1963), married to Einar’s sister Christiane and father of Einar’s nephew, Sigurd
brother (fictional), Andreas’s brother, modeled on Holger Wegener (b. 1880), brother of Einar Wegener
Brothers (fictional), modeled on Einar Wegener’s brothers, Holger (b. 1880) and Henrik
Count Mario di Carrobio (historical), unidentified but possibly Count Mario Gabrielli di Carpegna (1856-1924), an Italian soldier and politician
Casanova (historical), Giacomo Girolamo Casanova (1725-1798), an Italian author and womanizer
the Cripple (fictional), no known historical model. We chose this epithet over “newspaper boy” or “red-haired fellow” because it is precisely his hump that makes this character important to Andreas.
Colonel de T. (fictional), the historical figure mentioned in Allatini’s memoir is unidentified
cousin (fictional), historical figure unidentified
Cupid (fictional), the god of love in classical mythology
Maurice Diamond (historical), publisher with Jarrolds in London
Mrs. Louise Diel (historical, b. 1893), a German journalist and author
Director (historical), unidentified
Doctor F. (historical), historical figure unidentified
Wolfgang von Einsiedel (historical), German writer who reviewed the German edition in November 1932
Eisenlohr (historical), unidentified
Else Margrethe Wegener Thomsen (1907-2000), daughter of T. C. Thomsen and Christiane Wegener Thomsen and Sigurd Thomsen’s sister
Father (fictional), modeled on Einar Wegener’s father, Vilhelm Wegener
Favio (fictional), no known historical model
Ridolfo Feruzzi (fictional), modeled on Fernando Porta (b. 1897), Gerda Wegener’s second husband
Dr. Feuchtwanger (historical), likely Lion Feuchtwanger (1884-1958), a German-Jewish author well known in Weimar Germany and highly critical of the National Socialists
Favio (fictional), no known historical model
Marie Garland (1889-1967), Danish actress; married to Ernst Harthern
Théophile Gautier (1811-1872), a French novelist, author of Mademoiselle de Maupin (1835), in which the female protagonist, disguised as a man, seduces both a young woman and her lover
Professor Gebhard (fictional), modeled on Erwin Gohrbandt (1890–1965), a Berlin surgeon who performed the first operation on Lili Elvenes in 1930
German friend (fictional), modeled on Niels Hoyer, pseudonym of Ernst Harthern (1884–1969), editor of Man into Woman
Goethe (historical), Johann Wolfgang von Goethe (1749-1832), German writer and diplomat
Erwin Gohrbandt (1890–1965), a Berlin surgeon who performed the first operation on Lili Elvenes in 1930
Justine (née Østerberg) Gottlieb (historical), mother of Gerda Wegener (née Gottlieb)
Emil Gottlieb (historical), father of Gerda Wegener (née Gottlieb)
Martin Guggenheim (historical), a handwriting expert in Zurich (unconfirmed)
Charles Guyot (1892-1963?), French writer, co-author of Les Livres des Vikings (1924) with Einar Wegener
Norman Haire (1892-1952), an Australian-born physician and prominent sexologist who lived and worked in London

Professor Hardenfeld (fictional), modeled on Magnus Hirschfeld (1868–1935), a German physician and one of the most influential sexologists of the time; Einar Wegener was examined at his Institute in March 1930
Steen Hasselbalch (1881-1952), a Danish publisher
Ernst Ludwig Harthern (née Jacobson) (1884–1969), German writer and editor of Man into Woman under the pseudonym, Niels Hoyer; Lili’s German friend in the narrative
Hauwitz (fictional), no known historical model
Mr. Heinrich (first name unknown), employed by Carl Reissner Verlag, the German publishing house in Dresden
Hermes (fictional), in Greek mythology, son of Zeus and messenger of the gods
Heyman and Haslund (fictional and historical), Svend Heyman (1878–1931), Ole who owned Ole Huslands Hus with Georg Haslund (1877–1962), where the Wegeners exhibited in Copenhagen
Magnus Hirschfeld (1868–1935), a German physician and one of the most influential sexologists of the time; Einar Wegener was examined at his Institute in March 1930
Niels Hoyer (historical), pseudonym of Ernst Harthern, who composed and edited Man into Woman
Hvappe (fictional and historical), nicknamed Vâpe, the Wegeners’ (Sparres’) dog
Inger Hvide (fictional), modeled on Vibeke Knudsen (dates unknown), married to Poul Knudsen from 1925 to 1938
Niels Hvide (fictional), modeled on Poul Knudsen (1889-1974), Danish lawyer and writer, friend of the Wegeners, married to Vibeke 1925-1938
Hans Henrik Jæger (1854-1910), a Norweigen writer and political activist
Jean (fictional), no known historical model
Dr. Karner (fictional), historical figure unknown
Herta Heller (née Lederer) (1901-2000), of Czech origin, wife of Ewald Heller
King (fictional), modeled on Christian X, the King of Denmark from 1912 to 1947
Poul Knudsen (1889-1974), Danish lawyer and writer, friend of the Wegeners, married to Vibeke from 1925 to 1938
Vibeke Knudsen (dates unknown), married to Poul Knudsen from 1925 to 1938
Professor Werner Kreutz (fictional), modelled on Kurt Warenkros (1882–1949), a German gynecologist
Anna Larsen (fictional), modeled on Anna Larssen, a Danish actress, friend of the Wegeners
Anna Larssen (1875-1955), a Danish actress, friend of the Wegeners
Claude Lejeune (fictional), modeled on Claude Prévost, friend of Lili’s whom Gerda Wegener painted in 1923
Lili Elbe (fictional and historical), legal name Lili Ilse Elvenes; born Einar Wegener (1882), died in Dresden, 1931
Lovis Hans Lorenz (1898-1976), a German journalist, publisher, and author
Anna Lorenz (historical), unidentified
Louis XIV (1638-1715), King of France from 1643 until his death
Lousie (Loulou) Lassen (1876–1947), a Danish journalist who interviewed the Wegeners and assisted Lili in an early draft of her memoirs
Madame de B. (historical), unidentified
Erwin Magnus (historical), a German literary agent, author, and translator
Maurice Magre (1877-1941), a French author
Thomas Mann (1875-1955), a German novelist, essayist, and social critic who won the 1929 Nobel Prize in Literature. Ernst Harthern dedicates his 1938 memoir Going Home to Mann.
Gregorio Marañon (1887-1960), also spelled Marañón, a Spanish physician and author
Marquise de S.G. (historical), unidentified
Marquis (historical), husband of Marquise de S. G., unidentified

Matron (fictional), modeled on Margarete Leifert (possibly Seifert), who co-signed a letter (April 5, 1930) to the Ministry of Justice in Copenhagen conveying Lili’s request to change her name to Lili Elben and her sex to female
Einar Mellerup (1882-1968), a police inspector in Copenhagen
Mother (fictional), modeled on Einar Wegener’s mother, Ane Marie Wegener (née Thomsen)
Mrs. Teddybear (fictional), also Teddybearkins, no known historical model
Archbishop of Naples (historical), unidentified but possibly Guglielmo Sanfelice d’Acquavilla, Archbishop of Naples from 1878-1897
Nephew (fictional), modeled on Einar Wegener’s nephew, Harald Sigurd Wegener Thomsen (1905-1953), son of Christiane and Thomas C. Thomsen
niece (fictional), possibly modelled on Else, daughter of Einar Wegener’s sister
Nino (fictional), no known historical model
Ellen (fictional), no known historical model
Frieda (fictional), no known historical model
Hanna (fictional), no known historical model
Ilse (fictional), no known historical model
Margaret (fictional), no known historical model
Marianne (fictional), no known historical model
Dr. Palitzsch (historical), unidentified
Palma Vecchio (1480-1528), a Venetian painter
Pan (fictional), in Greek mythology, the god of nature
Dr. Paquet (historical), unidentified
Ebba Persen (fictional), modeled on Ulla Britta Poulsen Skou (née Iversen) (1905–2001), a Danish ballet dancer whom Gerda painted in Paris in 1927
Iven Persen (fictional), modeled on Johannes Poulsen (1881–1938), Danish actor and director, married to Ulla Poulsen
Pianist XX (fictional), no known historical model
Plato (b. 429 BC), an Athenian philosopher
Fernando Porta (b. 1897), Gerda Wegener’s second husband
Johannes Poulsen (1881–1938), Danish actor and director, married to Ulla Poulsen
Ulla Britta Poulsen Skou (née Iversen) (1905–2001), a Danish ballet dancer whom Gerda painted in Paris in 1927
Praxiteles (395-330 BC), an Athenian sculptor
Claude Prévost (historical), friend of Lili’s whom Gerda Wegener painted in 1923
Carl Reissner (historical), a German publisher in Dresden
Monsieur René (fictional), possibly modeled on a deputy mayor of Beaugency, Henri René Goujon
General Nicolis di Robilant (historical), likely Mario Nicolis di Robilant (1855-1943), an Italian General in WWI
Elena Rossini (fictional), modeled on Hélène Kann Allatini (1887-1943), friend of the Wegeners; author of Mosaiques
Ernesto Rossini (fictional), modeled on Eric Allatini (1886–1943), friend of the Wegeners; married to Hélène Allatini
Ruth (fictional and historical), modeled on Ruth Hanna Hathern-Thaning (dates unknown), daughter of Ernst Harthern
Fraulein Saunders (historical), unidentified
Baronin Schildt (fictional), modeled on Marie-Anne von Goldschmidt-Rothschild (née Friedländer-Fuld, 1892-1973), known as Baroness Rotschildt; a friend of Kurt Warnekros
Franz Schubert (1797-1828), a German composer
Elisabeth Schumann (1888-1952), a German opera singer
Harry Schumann (historical), head of Carl Reissner Verlag, the German publishing house in Dresden
Signora Favio (fictional), wife of Favio, no known historical model
Sister (fictional), modeled on Einar Wegener’s sister, Christiane Thomsen (1881–1954
Sister-in-law (fictional), modeled on Einar Wegener’s sister-in-law, Musse (a nickname), married to Holger Wegener
Andreas Sparre (fictional), modeled on Einar Magnus Andreas Wegener (b. 1882), a Danish painter
Grete Sparre (fictional), modeled on Gerda Wegener (1885-1940), an art deco painter and illustrator
Eugen Steinach (1861–1944), an Austrian physician who pioneered gonadal transplants and early theorized the existence of hormones
Karl Kristian Steincke (1880-1963), a Danish politician
H J Stenning (historical), translator of the English-language editions
Tacitus (d. 117 AD), a senator and a historian of the Roman Empire
T. B. (historical), an unidentified Danish diplomat
Jean Tempête (fictional), modeled on Léon Leyritz (1888-1976), French sculptor and friend of the Wegeners
Gabriele Tergit (1894-1982), a writer and journalist born in Berlin who was a courtroom reporter for the Berliner Tageblatt and published the novel Käsebier erobert den Kurfürstendamm in 1932
Thomas Christian Thomsen (1883-1963), married to Einar’s sister, Christiane Thomsen, and father of Einar’s nephew, Sigurd Thomsen
Toller (historical), possibly Ernst Toller (1893-1939), a German Expressionist playwright
Comte de Trempe (fictional), no known historical model
Palma Vecchio (1480-1528), a Venetian painter
Richard Wagner (1813-1883), a German composer
Karen Wardal (fictional), also Warren; possibly modeled on Sascha Wamberg, a Russian-born Danish woman living in Paris at the time and depicted in several painting by Gerda Wegener

Kurt Warenkros (1882–1949), a German gynecologist who performed all but the first of four surgeries on Lili Elvenes; director of the Women’s Clinic in Dresden (Staatliche Frauenklinik) from 1925 to 1948
Jean-Antoine Watteau ((1684-1721), a French painter
Ane Marie Wegener (historical), Einar Wegener’s mother
Einar Magnus Andreas Wegener (b. 1882), a Danish painter; married to Gerda Wegener; died as Lili Elbe in Dresden, 1931
Gerda Maria Frederikke Gottlieb Wegener (1885-1940), an art deco painter and illustrator; married to Einar Wegener
Henrik Wegener (historical), Einar Wegener’s brother
Holger Wegener (b. 1880), Einar Wegener’s brother
“Musse” (nickname) Wegener (historical), Holger Wegener’s wife
Sigurd Wegener Thomsen (1905-1953), Einar’s nephew
Vilhelm Wegener (historical), Einar Wegener’s father
Oscar Wilde (1854-1900), an Irish-born prominent British playwright and author imprisoned for “gross indecency” (homosexuality) in 1897
Zeus (fictional), in Greek mythology, the king of the gods
Zuckmayer (historical), likely Carl Zuckmayer (1896-1977), a German author
